Federated Learning based on Defending Against Data Poisoning Attacks in IoT

Jiayin Li, Wenzhong Guo,Â , Xingshuo Han, Jianping Cai, Ximeng Liu J. Li is with the College of Computer and Cyber Security, Fujian Normal University, Fuzhou, Fujian, China, 350117. W. Guo, J. Cai, X. Liu are with College of Computer and Data Science, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou, China, 350108; and Key Lab of Information Security of Network Systems (Fuzhou University), Fujian Province. X. Han is with School of Computer Science and Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore (email: lijiayin2019@gmail.com, guowenzhong@fzu.edu.cn, xingshuo.han@ntu.edu.sg, jpingcai@163.com, snbnix@gmail.com)Manuscript received xxx xx, xxxx; revised xxx xx, xxxx.
Abstract

The rapidly expanding number of Internet of Things (IoT) devices is generating huge quantities of data, but the data privacy and security exposure in IoT devices, especially in the automatic driving system. Federated learning (FL) is a paradigm that addresses data privacy, security, access rights, and access to heterogeneous message issues by integrating a global model based on distributed nodes. However, data poisoning attacks on FL can undermine the benefits, destroying the global modelâ€™s availability and disrupting the model training. To avoid the above issues, we build up a hierarchical defense data poisoning (HDDP) system framework to defend against data poisoning attacks in FL, which monitors each local model of individual nodes via abnormal detection to remove the malicious clients. Whether the poisoning defense server has a trusted test dataset, we design the local model test voting (LMTV) and kullback-leibler divergence anomaly parameters detection (KLAD) algorithms to defend against label-flipping poisoning attacks. Specifically, the trusted test dataset is utilized to obtain the evaluation results for each classification to recognize the malicious clients in LMTV. More importantly, we adopt the kullback leibler divergence to measure the similarity between local models without the trusted test dataset in KLAD. Finally, through extensive evaluations and against the various label-flipping poisoning attacks, LMTV and KLAD algorithms could achieve the 100%percent100100\% and 40%percent4040\% to 85%percent8585\% successful defense ratios under different detection situations.

Index Terms:
federated learning; data poisoning attacks; kullback-leibler divergence; anomaly model detection.

I Introduction

As represented autonomous vehicles Internet of Things (IoT) device number has increased dramatically, deep learning techniques have brought a paradigm in the variable application field, such as driven application [1], speech recognition [2], and image identification [3], which can use a large of history data to mine hidden patterns and make predictions about what will not happen in the future. As a result, people can optimize their travel time using deep learning techniques, significantly improving their work efficiency. Since traditional deep learning is a data-driven technique, the core of its performance is the size and quality of the training data, which is to train a usable network model through deep learning algorithms [4, 5] via collecting a mass of training dataset to store in a central server. Meanwhile, the privacy and security of data have been significantly compromised to bring a significant threat to peopleâ€™s lives and property [6, 7, 8] and violate the general data protection regulation (GDPR) legal provisions [9]. To address the above challenge, the federated learning (FL) approach is built up to avoid the problem of data privacy leakage and solve the disadvantages of training datasets islands [10, 11, 12]. Unlike traditional deep learning framework, the FL is similar to a distributed learning structure that greatly solves the drawbacks of small training datasets caused by data decentralization. It can better use various data resources to train a more accurate neural network prediction model. In addition, the FL breaks the barrier that different data owners can not share their private data without worrying about data leakage. Despite the advantages mentioned above, the FL increases the risk of malicious attacks [13, 14, 15]. A typical FL structure contains many local clients and a central server defined as the trusted parties. Due to the vast number of parties involved, each participant is not guaranteed to be an honest and credible entity, suffering from data poisoning attacks to reduce the prediction accuracy of the final model seriously [16, 17, 18].

The goal of data poisoning attacks is to attack the neural network model by breaking the distribution features of the training datasets, which are pervasive means for neural network vicious backdoor implantation to reach a specific purpose based on the attackerâ€™s intent [19, 20, 21]. When the training dataset suffers from data poisoning attacks, the trained network model based on the poisoned dataset can reduce the classification accuracy and lead to misclassified. Therefore, the above issues have laid an enormous security risk for applying neural networks, especially in the autonomous vehicles (AV) field, which leads to traffic accidents [22]. Similarly, the data poisoning attacks are commonly used to destroy the final global model by attacking many local clients involved in FL [23]. However, the existing defense approaches against data poisoning attacks are fundamental for building on the credible test dataset, and their defense success rate needs further improvement. Besides, it focuses on defending against data poisoning attacks without a trusted test dataset.

To guarantee the usability of the global predictive model and avoid data poisoning attacks in IoT, we propose a hierarchical defense data poisoning (HDDP) system against data poisoning attacks. Due to the local modelsâ€™ collaborative integration approach to obtaining the training model, the central server cannot receive the training dataset of each client to analyze the dataset. Thereby, the traditional approaches based on analyzing datasets were not suitable to reach the goal of finding poisoned local models in FL [24, 25, 26]. To extend the usefulness of our proposed HDDP for FL, we build up the HDDP system to defend against data poisoning attacks under different detection conditions in this paper. The significant contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

  • â€¢

    In this paper, we propose a hierarchical defense HDDP against data poisoning attacks in FL, which can contain two types of defending against the data poisoning attacks to remove the poisoned local models and decrease the poisoned local models to influence the performance of an aggregated global model.

  • â€¢

    To improve the performance of the defense mechanism against data poisoning attacks, we design a local model test voting (LMTV) algorithm based on the trusted test dataset to remove the poisoned local models. Specifically, we statistics the test classification results for each clientâ€™s local model for each round of interaction in FL, which can be regarded as the basis for voting.

  • â€¢

    To solve defense against data poisoning attacks in the absence of a trusted validation dataset, we also design a Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence anomaly parameters detection (KLAD) algorithm, which computes the KL divergence to remove the irrelevant poisoned local models without the trusted test dataset.

  • â€¢

    Finally, we implement the label-flipping attacks for data poisoning and evaluate the proposed defense algorithms via images classification based on Fashion-MINIST and GTSRB datasets to validate the efficiency and security of HDDP in FL, which reaches excellent performance.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we give the related work. In Section III, we describe the preliminary knowledge. Furthermore, the system architecture is defined in Section IV. Next, we give more detail about the defense algorithms in Section V. Section VI provides the security and performance analysis. We conclude the paper and provide future work in Section VII.

II Related Work

Data poisoning attacks are highly relevant for various application fields in IoT, which pose a severe security threat, such as computer vision [27], spam filtering [28, 29], and disease diagnosis [30]. In the beginning, several data poisoning attacks were studied to destroy some simple machine learning (ML) models containing support vector machine (SVM) [31, 32, 33], linear regression [34], and unsupervised learning [35], where data poisoning attacks researches could destroy the accuracy of the trained model by inserting some error data into original training data to disturb the distribution of training data. However, those data poisoning attacks only cause classification errors and do not achieve a specific target of poisoning attacks. To achieve purposeful data poisoning attacks, some target data poisoning attacks were proposed based on the will of malicious attackers [36, 37, 38]. For instance, the authors in [36] proposed a targeted backdoor attack to destroy the deep learning systems based on data poisoning, which realizes backdoor attacks by utilizing poisoning strategies (e.g., burying a specific back door) to achieve the adversarial goal of malicious attackers. Moreover, the backdoor key is hard to notice even by humans to achieve stealthiness. However, the target backdoor attacks approach is less robust. To improve the robustness of data poisoning attacks, Wang eâ€‹tğ‘’ğ‘¡et aâ€‹l.ğ‘ğ‘™al. [37] realized the data poisoning attacks against online learning to utilize a class of adversarial attacks on ML where an adversary has the power to alter a small fraction of the training data to make the trained classifier satisfy specific objectives. Nevertheless, it needs to have the ability to manipulate training data. Therefore, Zhao eâ€‹tğ‘’ğ‘¡et aâ€‹l.ğ‘ğ‘™al. [38] proposed using a universal adversarial trigger as the backdoor trigger to attack video recognition models, which is an identification error directly based on the attackerâ€™s intent. However, the above studies for data poisoning attacks are often limited to centralized neural network training, which does not work well in FL. To improve the success rate of data poisoning attacks in FL, Fang eâ€‹tğ‘’ğ‘¡et aâ€‹l.ğ‘ğ‘™al. [17, 23] proposed a local model of data poisoning attacks to destroy the FL, which assumes an attacker has compromised some client devices. During the learning process, the attacker manipulates the local modelsâ€™ parameters on the compromised client devices. Therefore, they could realize the label-flipping for the training dataset to impact some local clients in FL.

For defense approaches against data poisoning attacks, the existing defense approaches aim to sanitize the training dataset. One category of defenses was to analyze the distribution of the training dataset and detect the malicious dataset based on their negative impact on the error of obtained model [39, 40, 41]. Another category of defense approaches was to use the loss functions, optimizing the obtained model parameter to detect the injected malicious data simultaneously, which needs to jointly find a subset of the training dataset with a given size [42, 43]. Meanwhile, Peri eâ€‹tğ‘’ğ‘¡et aâ€‹l.ğ‘ğ‘™al. proposed a novel method by cleaning the error label to defend the data poisoning based on the deep-knn[44]. Additionally, Chen eâ€‹tğ‘’ğ‘¡et aâ€‹l.ğ‘ğ‘™al. effectively defended the data poisoning attack in machine learning by adopting the GAN network [45]. However, these defense approaches are not directly applicable to defense against the data poisoning attacks in FL because of the un-share of the local training datasets. For the defense algorithms in FL, there is also some literature to detect poisoning local models [46, 47]. Whatever these local model poisoning detection approaches that were implemented needed to be established based on the trusted test dataset. In addition, privacy breaches are risky during data poisoning detection. Designing the defense algorithm against data poisoning attacks is essential based on a credible verification dataset.

III Preliminary

In this section, we introduce the basic knowledge to illustrate the detail of the data poisoning defense mechanism such as federated learning and Paillier cryptography.

III-A Federated Learning

Unlike traditional centralized deep learning framework, federated learning (FL) was proposed in the literature [48] as a new training structure, which could ensure the privacy of private data and solve the data island. To call multiple resources, the FL has two substructures: many local clients and a central server. The function of local clients is to train local models based on their dataset without sharing the dataset. After each local client generates the local model, the central server can receive each local model to integrate the global model. Thereby, many local clientsâ€™ interaction with the central server realizes the core of FL. To achieve the global model, the central server adopts the simple parameter average approach named FedAvg algorithm [49]. More details about FL can be expressed as follows.

I. The central server initializes the training model Gâ€‹M0ğºsubscriptğ‘€0GM_{0}, which is sent to each participant client iâ€‹(0<iâ‰¤n)ğ‘–0ğ‘–ğ‘›i\;(0<i\leq n).

II. When each client receives the initialized model Gâ€‹M0ğºsubscriptğ‘€0GM_{0}, the many local clients will update the Gâ€‹M0ğºsubscriptğ‘€0GM_{0} to generate a local model Lâ€‹M(i,j)ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘—LM_{(i,j)}, where jâ€‹(0<jâ‰¤m)ğ‘—0ğ‘—ğ‘šj\;(0<j\leq m) is the number of rounds of interactive communication between the local clients and the central server.

III. After each round, the central server could receive the local model Lâ€‹M(i,j)ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘—LM_{(i,j)} and further obtain the global model as the following formula.

Gâ€‹Mj=âˆ‘i=1nLâ€‹M(i,j)nğºsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘›GM_{j}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}{LM_{(i,j)}}}{n} (1)

Here, the end of model training sign is that the loss function reaches convergence.

III-C Data Poisoning Attacks

For the honest-but-curious (HBC) parties in FL, they passively observe the other data gathered from the clients to learn private messages about clientsâ€™ datasets. Therefore, the FL is constantly being attacked by data poisoning. Unlike several known adversarial learning techniques reducing the accuracy of the predictive model, the data poisoning could trigger the classification error and accuracy drop to cause the unavailability of the training model based on a training dataset. For instance, the attackers can modify the test data to avoid the detection of malicious samples on a well-trained model [50, 51, 52, 53, 54, 55]. In this paper, we focus on target attacks and un-target attacks for data poisoning, which utilizes the training data to affect the global model accuracy and classification performance during the learning phase [56]. Assume that the function â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is the learning algorithm to train the predictive model. The fğ‘“f is the data poisoning attacks algorithm if the malicious local clients obtain the poisoned dataset ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*} from the benign dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, they only execute the function fğ‘“f is the following formula.

fâ€‹(ğ’Ÿ)âŸ¶ğ’Ÿâˆ—âŸ¶ğ‘“ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿf(\mathcal{D})\longrightarrow\mathcal{D}^{*} (3)

To realize the function fğ‘“f, the traditional approaches generate the error label to lead the error characteristics. Significantly, the poisoned training dataset ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*} contains incorrect classification labels, which is very easy to distinguish the feature of the object ağ‘a into the feature of the object bğ‘b. Thereby, the poisoned predictive model Gâ€‹Mâˆ—ğºsuperscriptğ‘€GM^{*} can be obtained based on the ğ’Ÿâˆ—superscriptğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}^{*} and learning algorithm â„±â„±\mathcal{F}, such as.

ğ’Ÿâˆ—âŸ¶â„±Gâ€‹Mâˆ—superscriptâŸ¶â„±superscriptğ’Ÿğºsuperscriptğ‘€\mathcal{D}^{*}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathcal{F}}}{{\longrightarrow}}GM^{*} (4)

Where the Gâ€‹Mâˆ—ğºsuperscriptğ‘€GM^{*} will not achieve the correct classification of particular specific objects.

IV System Architecture

We aim to defend the impact of data poisoning attacks in FL and guarantee clientsâ€™ privacy. Here, we build up the system model, define the attack model and further give the systemâ€™s goal designed in this section.

IV-A System Model

In favor of the designed goal in this paper, we build up the system framework and solve the data poisoning defense mechanism to avoid the data poisoning attacks for object detection in IoT, which contains the vehicular clients training, data poisoning attacks, poisoning defense mechanism, and secure model aggregation as the Fig. 1.

  • â€¢

    Vehicular Client Trainers (VCT). Vehicular client training is the first component to build up the local model by utilizing their dataset to train the model in the system model. And then, the vehicular clients (VCs) send the trained local model to the defense poisoning server. However, due to the vast number of participating VCs based on local models aggregation in FL, the system can not guarantee that each local vehicular client can honestly submit the benign model to the central server. On the contrary, malicious VCs could generate the poisoned local models to decrease the nature of the aggregated global model. Similarly, the VCs may be at risk of being attacked by malicious attackers without their knowledge providing the poisoned local models.

  • â€¢

    Data Poisoning Attackers (DPA). Data poisoning attacks are a common means to influence the performance-trained model in practical applications. This paper focuses on the label-flipping attacks in data poisoning to influence the FL. Furthermore, the label-flipping attacks are carried out to control and modify their vehicular dataset by malicious VCs or attackers. Malicious VCs and attackers aim to make the trained models achieve a specific classification for an error object according to their desired goal. Meanwhile, the poisoned models obtained are also sent and joined in global model integration.

  • â€¢

    Poisoning Defense Server (PDS). Poisoning defense server is an authenticated and a trusted party whose core function is designed in the system model to eliminate VCsâ€™ submitted poisoned local models. According to the algorithms we designed, the local models submitted must be detected to determine whether the local models are attacked before parameters collaborative integration. After detecting the data poisoning defense algorithms, the benign local models are saved to integrate with the usable global model.

  • â€¢

    Model Aggregation Server (MAS) The MAS is also an HBC party, curious about the VCsâ€™ privacy but can perform the mechanism designed precisely as we want. When the poisoned local models are eliminated, the remaining benign ones are aggregated to generate a global model without decrypting the ciphertext of local modelsâ€™ parameters in MAS. Finally, the usable global model is sent to the benign VCs.

IV-B Attack Model

For data poisoning attacks in FL, we consider the constrained condition Ï„ğœ\tau for the participated clients. The Ï„ğœ\tau means the number of malicious clients, which usually need to satisfy 0<Ï„<n20ğœğ‘›20<\tau<\frac{n}{2} to avoid detection easily for data poisoning attacks [46]. Note that nğ‘›n is the total amount of participantsâ€™ clients. There are usually two different aspects of data poisoning to destroy the predicted ability of generated globe model in collaborative learning. One is called malicious clients that part some of the participating clients are malicious, which could control their dataset to reach the effect of destroying their model to impact the globe model. Another is called malicious attackers ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} that the participating clients may be attacked by the malicious attackers, which also modified the training dataset and triggered the data poisoning. To further state the attack process, we assume that all the adversaries know the learning algorithm used by each participating client. We can tamper with the training data accordingly (e.g., by adding fake data or mislabeling the training data). However, all the malicious users cannot collude together to poison their data and learn the globe model be-forehead as the malicious users know the training data generated from benign users.

IV-C Problem Definition

To illustrate the function of label-flipping attacks, we definite two indexes to measure the deep of label-flipping attacks, such as classification error and accuracy reduction.

Definition 1

(Classification Error) In data poisoning attacks, the attackers gave the source data ğ’®dsubscriptğ’®d\mathcal{S}_{d}, the global model Gâ€‹Mâˆ—GsuperscriptMGM^{*} could output the target data ğ’¯dsubscriptğ’¯d\mathcal{T}_{d} according to the attackerâ€™s wish, such as ğ’®dâ†’ğ’¯dâ†’subscriptğ’®dsubscriptğ’¯d\mathcal{S}_{d}\rightarrow\mathcal{T}_{d}. Here, the ğ’®dsubscriptğ’®d\mathcal{S}_{d} is an input value to the global model for which the attacker wants to influence the modelâ€™s output. The ğ’¯dsubscriptğ’¯d\mathcal{T}_{d} is a value of the attackerâ€™s choice that the influenced model should output for a given source input. The poisoning precision rate Pâ€‹rPrPr is defined as the following formula to measure the degree of data poisoning.

IV-D Design Goal

To defend against the impact of data poisoning (e.g., target attack and random poisoning attack), the system design aims to ensure classification correctness, defense success rate, and prediction model accuracy.

  • â€¢

    Classification Correctness Rate: To avoid the harm of data poisoning attacks, the system model can eliminate the malicious attackersâ€™ attacks on specific targets. More importantly, the system model should also be able to reject poisoned local clients from resubmitting models.

  • â€¢

    Defense Success Rate: The data poisoning defense success rate is another more important index to measure the efficiency of the poisoning defense algorithm, which is about the performance required to prevent the global model from the data poisoning attacks of local models from generating a practicable global model in FL, especially in the IoT.

  • â€¢

    Prediction Model Accuracy: For random data poisoning attacks, the higher the number of poisoned VCs, the lower the accuracy of the obtained global model prediction. The system model must detect the malicious local models to reduce the impact of poisoned local clientsâ€™ models submitted for the global model.

V Defense Mechanism in Federated Learning

In this section, we mainly detail the hierarchical defense data poisoning model to eliminate the submitted local poisoned models. We give the following aspects: a system overview and the details about building the system.

V-A System Overview

To facilitate the introduction of the system, we show a system overview. It contains four parts: training dataset generation, local models training, poisoning defense mechanism, and secure model aggregation, whose structure level is similar to an erect triangle. A brief overview of these stages is given in Fig. 2.

  • â€¢

    Training Dataset Generation: From Fig. 2, the training dataset generation is the basis for building up by utilizing the traditional FL structure. They are generated by the participating vehicles in the IVN, which also are stored in their own storage space to train the corresponding predictive models. Suppose that there are nğ‘›n vehicles participating in collaborative learning training to generate the global model together. Each vehicle Viâˆˆ[1,n]subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–1ğ‘›V_{i\in[1,n]} can obtain the corresponding training images dataset ğ’³iâˆˆ[1,n]subscriptğ’³ğ‘–1ğ‘›\mathcal{X}_{i\in[1,n]} collected by the in-vehicle cameras. Therefore, the ğ’³isubscriptğ’³ğ‘–\mathcal{X}_{i} is regarded as the training dataset to execute the following steps.

  • â€¢

    Local Models Training: Local models training is the second step to realizing the whole system and is also the process of generating a large of local predictive models. After the training dataset generation, the initialized global model parameter is sent to each VC and utilizes their images as a training dataset to train the local model. Similarly, each vehicle Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} could train its local modelâ€™s parameters set Lâ€‹Miğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–LM_{i}. Thereby, nğ‘›n vehicles can compose a model vector M=[Lâ€‹M1,Lâ€‹M2,â‹¯,Lâ€‹Mn]ğ‘€ğ¿subscriptğ‘€1ğ¿subscriptğ‘€2â‹¯ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›M=[LM_{1},LM_{2},\cdots,LM_{n}]. To guarantee the security of generated local modelsâ€™ parameters, we adopt Paillier cryptography to prevent the submitted local models from being reversed by malicious VCs and attackers.

  • â€¢

    Poisoning Defense Mechanism: The poisoning defense mechanism is the core component for the HDDP designed to distinguish whether the submitted local models have been poisoned in the PDS. If the submitted models suffer from data poisoning attacks, the HDDP will clear the poisoned model to eliminate the impact on the integrated global model. To execute the poisoning defense mechanism, the PDS needs to construct the queue ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} for receiving a large of submitted local modelsâ€™ parameter sets. According to the definition in the above rounds of local model training, the ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} can be presented as ğ’¬=[Lâ€‹M(1,k),Lâ€‹M(2,k),â‹¯,Lâ€‹M(n,k)]ğ’¬ğ¿subscriptğ‘€1ğ‘˜ğ¿subscriptğ‘€2ğ‘˜â‹¯ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›ğ‘˜\mathcal{Q}=[LM_{(1,k)},LM_{(2,k)},\cdots,LM_{(n,k)}], where the kğ‘˜k represents the count of the PDS receiving local model, which is the number of rounds during local model training. When ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} is verified by the poisoning defense algorithm, the system will eliminate the poisoned local modelsâ€™ parameters set from ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}.

  • â€¢

    Secure Model Announcement: When the poisoned local models are eliminated from the queue ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}, the MAS will integrate the submitted benign local models ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²\mathcal{Q}^{\prime} to generate the global model Gâ€‹Mğºğ‘€GM based on the classical FedAvg aggregation algorithm, such as ğ’¬âŸ¶Fâ€‹eâ€‹dâ€‹Aâ€‹vâ€‹gGâ€‹MsuperscriptâŸ¶ğ¹ğ‘’ğ‘‘ğ´ğ‘£ğ‘”ğ’¬ğºğ‘€\mathcal{Q}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle FedAvg}}{{\longrightarrow}}GM. And then, each benign VC receives the benign Gâ€‹Mğºğ‘€GM from MAS and further uploads the new local model for the next round.

V-B Secure Local Models Submission

According to the system model mentioned in section IV, the VCT train the local models Lâ€‹Mğ¿ğ‘€LM via their images ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}, such as.

ğ’³âŸ¶â„±Lâ€‹MsuperscriptâŸ¶â„±ğ’³ğ¿ğ‘€\mathcal{X}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathcal{F}}}{{\longrightarrow}}LM (7)

Owing to exist of the malicious VCs or malicious attacker ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, the trained local models may be poisoned. Assume that there are Ï„â€‹(0<Ï„<n2)ğœ0ğœğ‘›2\tau\;(0<\tau<\frac{n}{2}) poisoned local models, which can be indicated as Lâ€‹Mâˆ—ğ¿superscriptğ‘€LM^{*} to form poisoned models queue Qâˆ—superscriptğ‘„Q^{*}. Therefore, the whole local queue is also expressed, such as Q=[Qâ€²,Qâˆ—]ğ‘„superscriptğ‘„â€²superscriptğ‘„Q=[Q^{\prime},Q^{*}]. To ensure the safety of each local model transmission, we adopt Paillier cryptography to achieve the ciphertext for each local modelâ€™s parameters. Specifically, the PDS randomly chooses two large eâˆ’limit-fromğ‘’e-bit primes p1,q1subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘1p_{1},q_{1}, which satisfies the least common multiple relationship Î»=lâ€‹câ€‹mâ€‹(p1âˆ’1,q1âˆ’1)ğœ†ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘11subscriptğ‘11\lambda=lcm(p_{1}-1,q_{1}-1). To avoid the leakage of a private message from local models, it performs the following encryption steps before each vehicle Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} sends their local modelâ€™s parameters set Lâ€‹Miğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–LM_{i} to the PDS:

V-C Hierarchical Defense Data Poisoning Attacks

In this section, we mainly state more detail about the HDDP system and further describe the execution of the HDDP. To better accomplish the data poisoning defense mechanism, we design two types of data poisoning defense mechanisms to defend against two different situations. One is that we design a local model test voting (LMTV) mechanism with the trusted test dataset ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test} in PDS; another is that we also design a Kullback-Leibler divergence anomaly parameters detection (KLAD) mechanism without the ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test}.

V-C1 LMTV Defense Mechanism

When a each Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} submits its ciphertext cLâ€‹Misubscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–c_{LM_{i}}, nğ‘›n number cLâ€‹Miâˆˆ[1,n]subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–1ğ‘›c_{LM_{i\in[1,n]}} could construct the ciphertext vector cğ’¬subscriptğ‘ğ’¬c_{\mathcal{Q}}, such like cğ’¬=[cLâ€‹M1,cLâ€‹M2,â‹¯,cLâ€‹Mnâˆ’1,cLâ€‹Mn]subscriptğ‘ğ’¬subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›c_{\mathcal{Q}}=[c_{LM_{1}},c_{LM_{2}},\cdots,c_{LM_{n-1}},c_{LM_{n}}]. Suppose that the PDS have a trusted test dataset ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test}, which is utilized to detect whether the submitted local models have suffered from a data poisoning attacks and further remove the poisoned VCs as follows.

I. Because the PDS is an authenticated and trusted party, PDS utilizes the secret key sâ€‹k=(Î»,Î¼)ğ‘ ğ‘˜ğœ†ğœ‡sk=(\lambda,\mu) to decrypt the ciphertext vector cğ’¬subscriptğ‘ğ’¬c_{\mathcal{Q}}, such like cğ’¬=[cLâ€‹M1,cLâ€‹M2,â‹¯,cLâ€‹Mnâˆ’1,cLâ€‹Mn]subscriptğ‘ğ’¬subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›c_{\mathcal{Q}}=[c_{LM_{1}},c_{LM_{2}},\cdots,c_{LM_{n-1}},c_{LM_{n}}] to obtain the plaintext models vector ğ’¬=[Lâ€‹M1,Lâ€‹M2,â‹¯,Lâ€‹Mnâˆ’1,Lâ€‹Mn]ğ’¬ğ¿subscriptğ‘€1ğ¿subscriptğ‘€2â‹¯ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›1ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›\mathcal{Q}=[LM_{1},LM_{2},\cdots,LM_{n-1},LM_{n}].

II. And then, the PDS evaluates each local model submitted to give the classification of the natural objects based on the trusted ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test}. And then, the classification accuracy rate (Câ€‹Aâ€‹R)ğ¶ğ´ğ‘…(CAR) for each object classification is computed as the following formula.

Câ€‹Aâ€‹R=nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(oâ€‹bâ€‹j)âˆ’nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(oâ€‹bâ€‹jâˆ—)nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(oâ€‹bâ€‹j)â‹…100%ğ¶ğ´ğ‘…â‹…ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘superscriptğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘ğ‘—percent100CAR=\frac{num(obj)-num(obj^{*})}{num(obj)}\cdot 100\% (8)

Where the nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(oâ€‹bâ€‹jâˆ—)ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘superscriptğ‘—num(obj^{*}) and nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(oâ€‹bâ€‹j)ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘ğ‘—num(obj) are the number of the error classification by the each local model, respectively. The value of nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(oâ€‹bâ€‹jâˆ—)ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘superscriptğ‘—num(obj^{*}) and nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(oâ€‹bâ€‹j)ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘ğ‘—num(obj) can be obtained by confusion matrices.

III. According to those mentioned above, the number of poisoned local models Ï„ğœ\tau satisfies the relationship of 0<Ï„<n20ğœğ‘›20<\tau<\frac{n}{2}. Therefore, the PDS implements a defense mechanism against poisoned local models based on CARâ€™s value. Specifically, when each local model Lâ€‹Miğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–LM_{i} is detected, the PDS could calculate the value of Câ€‹Aâ€‹Rğ¶ğ´ğ‘…CAR for each classification based on ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test}. As for Câ€‹Aâ€‹Rğ¶ğ´ğ‘…CAR of each classification of local model Lâ€‹Miğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–LM_{i} in nğ‘›n local models, if the 50%â‰¤Câ€‹Aâ€‹Rpercent50ğ¶ğ´ğ‘…50\%\leq CAR, the PDS regards the local model Lâ€‹Miğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–LM_{i} detected at this time as a normal model and is retained. Conversely, if 0<Câ€‹Aâ€‹R<50%0ğ¶ğ´ğ‘…percent500<CAR<50\%, the PDS regards the local model Lâ€‹Miğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–LM_{i} detected as a poisoned model and is further eliminated.

IV. After detecting each local model, the PDS uses the public key pâ€‹k=(N,g)ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘”pk=(N,g) to encrypt the benign local models and obtain the ciphertext. Finally, the ciphertext cLâ€‹Miâ€²â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â€²ğ‘–c^{\prime}_{LM^{\prime}_{i}} of many benign local models Lâ€‹Miâ€²ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â€²ğ‘–LM^{\prime}_{i} will be composing the benign vector ğ’¬â€²superscriptğ’¬â€²\mathcal{Q}^{\prime}, which is sent to MAS.

According to the above execution, we can achieve the data poisoning defense mechanism based on the trusted test dataset ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test}. The above process can be given as algorithm 1.

V-C2 KLAD Defense Mechanism

For the LMTV mechanism, the trusted test dataset ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test} in PDS is a prerequisite for data poisoning defense. If there is no test dataset in PDS, we can not use the LMTV algorithm to defend against data poisoning attacks. To address the above issue, we give a new data poisoning mechanism named KLAD. The critical point of KLAD is to measure the correlation relationship between any two local models. Here, we provide the specific formula representation of the calculation formula for KL divergence, such as.

ÎºKâ€‹L(X||Y)=â„‹(X)âˆ’â„‹(Y)=âˆ‘xâˆˆX,yâˆˆYp(x)â‹…logpâ€‹(x)pâ€‹(y)\kappa_{KL}(X||Y)=\mathcal{H}(X)-\mathcal{H}(Y)=\sum_{x\in X,y\in Y}p(x)\cdot log\frac{p(x)}{p(y)} (9)

where the Yğ‘ŒY are the random variable sets, â„‹â€‹(X,Y)â„‹ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ\mathcal{H}(X,Y) is the joint probability distribution function of Xğ‘‹X and Yğ‘ŒY. The â„‹â€‹(X,Y)â„‹ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ\mathcal{H}(X,Y) can be computed by the information entropy â„‹â€‹(X)â„‹ğ‘‹\mathcal{H}(X) by the formula â„‹â€‹(X)=âˆ’âˆ‘xâˆˆXpâ€‹(x)â€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹gâ€‹(pâ€‹(x))â„‹ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘ğ‘¥\mathcal{H}(X)=-\sum_{x\in X}p(x)log(p(x)) and the â„‹â€‹(Y)â„‹ğ‘Œ\mathcal{H}(Y) can be get by â„‹â€‹(Y)=âˆ’âˆ‘yâˆˆYpâ€‹(y)â€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹gâ€‹(pâ€‹(Y))â„‹ğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘Œğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘ğ‘Œ\mathcal{H}(Y)=-\sum_{y\in Y}p(y)log(p(Y)).

To use the kullback-leibler divergence ÎºKâ€‹Lâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğœ…ğ¾ğ¿â‹…\kappa_{KL}(\cdot) to measure the correlation relationship between two models, we calculate Îºğœ…\kappa for the model parameters of each layer of the network. More details about the KLAD can be given as follows.

I. Firstly, when the PDS receives the ciphertext vector cğ’¬=[cLâ€‹M1,cLâ€‹M2,â‹¯,cLâ€‹Mnâˆ’1,cLâ€‹Mn]subscriptğ‘ğ’¬subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›c_{\mathcal{Q}}=[c_{LM_{1}},c_{LM_{2}},\cdots,c_{LM_{n-1}},c_{LM_{n}}], the PDS will also decrypt the cğ’¬subscriptğ‘ğ’¬c_{\mathcal{Q}} to obtain the plaintext ğ’¬=[Lâ€‹M1,Lâ€‹M2,â‹¯,Lâ€‹Mnâˆ’1,Lâ€‹Mn]ğ’¬ğ¿subscriptğ‘€1ğ¿subscriptğ‘€2â‹¯ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›1ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›\mathcal{Q}=[LM_{1},LM_{2},\cdots,LM_{n-1},LM_{n}] based on the secret key (Î»,Î¼)ğœ†ğœ‡(\lambda,\mu), such as Lâ€‹Mi=Dâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹(Lâ€‹Mi)=Lâ€‹(cLâ€‹MiÎ»)âˆ—Î¼modNğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ·ğ‘’ğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–moduloğ¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğœ†ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğœ‡ğ‘LM_{i}=Dec(LM_{i})=L(c^{\lambda}_{LM_{i}})*\mu\mod N.

II. And then, the plaintext for each local modelâ€™s parameters can be divide into Lğ¿L parts based on the number of layer of network model in the PDS. For instance, as for local models Lâ€‹Miâˆˆ[1,n]ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–1ğ‘›LM_{i\in[1,n]}, whose the network structure ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} has four layer â„’Ï‰âˆˆ[1,4]Lâ€‹Mi=[Ï‰1(Lâ€‹Mi,â„’1),Ï‰2(Lâ€‹Mi,â„’1),Ï‰3(Lâ€‹Mi,â„’1),Ï‰4(Lâ€‹Mi,â„’1)]subscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğœ”14subscriptsuperscriptğœ”ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptâ„’11subscriptsuperscriptğœ”ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptâ„’12subscriptsuperscriptğœ”ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptâ„’13subscriptsuperscriptğœ”ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptâ„’14\mathcal{L}^{{LM}_{i}}_{\omega\in[1,4]}=[\omega^{(LM_{i},\mathcal{L}_{1})}_{1},\omega^{(LM_{i},\mathcal{L}_{1})}_{2},\omega^{(LM_{i},\mathcal{L}_{1})}_{3},\omega^{(LM_{i},\mathcal{L}_{1})}_{4}].

III. The function Fğ¹F can be indicated as follows.

Fâ€‹(â„’Lâ€‹Mi,â„’Lâ€‹Mj)=âˆ‘i=1LÎº(Kâ€‹L,i)|L|ğ¹superscriptâ„’ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–superscriptâ„’ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ¿ğ‘–1subscriptğœ…ğ¾ğ¿ğ‘–ğ¿F(\mathcal{L}^{{LM}_{i}},\mathcal{L}^{{LM}_{j}})=\frac{\sum^{L}_{i=1}{\kappa_{(KL,\;i)}}}{|L|} (10)

IV. According to step 3 above, the PDS could get nğ‘›n number of Fğ¹F. Ï=|Fiâˆ’F~||F~|ğœŒsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–~ğ¹~ğ¹\rho=\frac{|F_{i}-\tilde{F}|}{|\tilde{F}|} (11)

Based on the above steps, we could realize the KLAD without the trusted dataset ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test} to achieve the defense data poisoning attacks. Thereby, the above steps can be shown as algorithm 2, and the defense algorithm chose like the flow chart as Fig. 3.

V-D Secure Global Aggregation

After execution based on LMTV and KLAD, the PDS removes the poisoned local models and saves the benign local models. Suppose that the MAS receives the ciphertexts for mğ‘šm benign local models, such as ğ’¬â€²=[cLâ€‹M1â€²,cLâ€‹M2â€²,â‹¯,cLâ€‹Mmâ€²]superscriptğ’¬â€²subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â€²1subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â€²2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â€²ğ‘š\mathcal{Q}^{\prime}=[c_{LM^{\prime}_{1}},c_{LM^{\prime}_{2}},\cdots,c_{LM^{\prime}_{m}}], where the mğ‘šm is the number of benign local models submitted. The MAS can achieve the aggregation for a secure global model in the following steps.

I. As for each cLâ€‹Miâ€²subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â€²ğ‘–c_{LM^{\prime}_{i}}, the MAS computes the value of mğ‘šm root, such as (Eâ€‹nâ€‹câ€‹(Lâ€‹Miâ€²))1m=(cLâ€‹Miâ€²)1msuperscriptğ¸ğ‘›ğ‘ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â€²ğ‘–1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘€â€²ğ‘–1ğ‘š(Enc(LM^{\prime}_{i}))^{\frac{1}{m}}={(c_{LM^{\prime}_{i}}})^{\frac{1}{m}}.

II. VI Security & Performance Analysis

To illustrate the security of the proposed defense algorithms based on the defined attack model, we give the security and performance analysis of the HDDP in this section.

VI-A Security Analysis

According to the definition of the attack model, two different directions of data poisoning attacks exist to influence the performance of the global model. A type of data poisoning attack comes from the malicious VCs, and another type of data poisoning attack is from the malicious attacker ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, which has the same hazard of misclassifying data to lead to the classification error and accuracy reduction of the global model. For instance, the poisoned local model could classify the source target 00 into poisoning target 222. To illustrate the global modelâ€™s effectiveness and the defense against the attacks of malicious VCs and attackers ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, the proofs are given to state the correctness of the HDDP system.

Theorem 1

The HDDP system effectively guarantees the security of local models, ensuring that the local modelsâ€™ parameters are not leaked during the transmission process. Even if the local models are stolen during transmission to PDS, the attackers ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} cannot obtain any private message.

Proof 1

As the content mentioned above, the system can generate â„³â„³\mathcal{M} local models based on â„³â„³\mathcal{M} VCs. To protect the transmission of each local modelâ€™s parameters, the third trusted party PDS generates the key (Î»,Î¼)ğœ†ğœ‡(\lambda,\mu) and (N,g)ğ‘ğ‘”(N,g) according to the Pallier cryptography theory are sent to each VC. Specifically, when the local models are generated, the VCs utilize the pâ€‹k=(N,g)ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘”pk=(N,g) to compute the ciphertext cLâ€‹Misubscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–c_{LM_{i}} of each local model, such as cLâ€‹Miâˆˆ[1,â„³]=Eâ€‹nâ€‹câ€‹(Lâ€‹Mi)=gLâ€‹Miâ‹…rNmodN2subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–1â„³ğ¸ğ‘›ğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–moduloâ‹…superscriptğ‘”ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘superscriptğ‘2c_{LM_{i\in[1,\mathcal{M}]}}=Enc(LM_{i})=g^{LM_{i}}\cdot r^{N}\mod N^{2}. From the security of Paillier cryptography [57], the transmission process could guarantee the safety of local modelsâ€™ parameters. Even if the malicious attacker ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} obtains the ciphertext cLâ€‹Misubscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–c_{LM_{i}}, he can not infer the whole plaintext of local models. More importantly, when the ciphertext cLâ€‹Misubscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–c_{LM_{i}} is sent to the PDS, all data processing is performed offline in PDS. Therefore, the HDDP system can ensure VCsâ€™ private information is secure.

Theorem 2

The HDDP effectively defense the data poisoning attacks of malicious VCs to remove the poisoned local models. Based on the HDDP defense mechanisms, the final global model will not be affected in FL, which effectively defense the attack of malicious VCs.

Proof 2

In this paper, we design two types of defense algorithms called LMTV and KLAD to defend against FL data poisoning attacks.

VI-A1 Proof of LMTV

As for the LMTV algorithm, the system mainly uses the trusted test dataset ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test} to verify each local model for the threat of data poisoning attacks. Specifically, when the PDS receives the ciphertext of the nğ‘›n local models, it goes offline to calculate the plaintext of each local model via Lâ€‹Miâˆˆ[1,â„³]=Dâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹(cLâ€‹Mi)=Lâ€‹(cLâ€‹MiÎ»)â‹…Î¼modNğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–1â„³ğ·ğ‘’ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–moduloâ‹…ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğœ†ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğœ‡ğ‘LM_{i\in[1,\mathcal{M}]}=Dec(c_{LM_{i}})=L(c^{\lambda}_{LM_{i}})\cdot\mu\mod N to construct the model vector ğ’¬=[Lâ€‹M1,Lâ€‹M2,â‹¯,Lâ€‹Mn]ğ’¬ğ¿subscriptğ‘€1ğ¿subscriptğ‘€2â‹¯ğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›\mathcal{Q}=[LM_{1},LM_{2},\cdots,LM_{n}]. Because the PDS is the trusted third party and the above operations are performed offline, the PDS can not reveal the leakage of any private messages about each local modelâ€™s parameters and protect the malicious attacker ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} from obtaining the plaintext information through the internet. To realize the defense algorithm for data poisoning attacks, the LMTV needs to achieve the classification confusion matrix to estimate every classification for every categorical label respectively based on the ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test} in each epoch. For nğ‘›n local models in every round, the system computes Câ€‹Aâ€‹Rğ¶ğ´ğ‘…CAR to obtain the each local model voting classification with different rates by calculating Câ€‹Aâ€‹R=nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(oâ€‹bâ€‹j)âˆ’nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(oâ€‹bâ€‹jâˆ—)/nâ€‹uâ€‹mâ€‹(oâ€‹bâ€‹j)â‹…100%ğ¶ğ´ğ‘…ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘ğ‘—â‹…ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘superscriptğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘ğ‘—percent100CAR={num(obj)-num(obj^{*})}/{num(obj)}\cdot 100\%. When Câ€‹Aâ€‹R>50%ğ¶ğ´ğ‘…percent50CAR>50\% means inconsistent classification voting with nğ‘›n local models, the system will consider the few inconsistent ones as poisoned local models to execute the elimination operation. Since the number of prescribed poisoned local models, Ï„ğœ\tau is between 0<Ï„<n20ğœğ‘›20<\tau<\frac{n}{2}, the system can use the LMTV algorithm both to avoid the effects of local dataset differences and to eliminate poisoned local models that are inconsistent with the majority of model classifications.

VI-A2 Proof of KLAD

Different from the LMTV algorithm, KLAD can realize the poisoning defense without the test dataset ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test}. Here, the system mainly utilizes the KL divergence to calculate the correlation relationship between different local models. According to the attribution, the correlation between the poisoned local models and the friendly model shows a different relationship; the deeper the modelâ€™s poisoning, the weaker the correlation between it and the benign local models. Specifically, when the PDS receives the ciphertext of local models cQsubscriptğ‘ğ‘„c_{Q}, the PDS decrypts the ciphertext vector cQsubscriptğ‘ğ‘„c_{Q} to obtain the plaintext vector of local models ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} via the private key sâ€‹k=(Î»,Î¼)ğ‘ ğ‘˜ğœ†ğœ‡sk=(\lambda,\mu). Owing to the above operations being performed offline, the PDS is protected from the malicious attacker ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} to steal the private message sourcing from each local modelâ€™s parameters. To accomplish the defense algorithm, the PDS randomly selects the local model Lâ€‹Miğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–LM_{i} to divide the plaintext of the local model into Lğ¿L parts based on the number of layers in-network ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W}. And then, the ÎºKâ€‹Lâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğœ…ğ¾ğ¿â‹…\kappa_{KL}(\cdot) of each layer is also computed to further obtain the metric function ÎºKâ€‹Lâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğœ…ğ¾ğ¿â‹…\kappa_{KL}(\cdot) between local model Lâ€‹Miğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–LM_{i} and Lâ€‹Mjğ¿subscriptğ‘€ğ‘—LM_{j} in each epoch, such as ÎºKâ€‹L(LMi||LMj)=â„‹(LMi)âˆ’â„‹(LMi,LMj)\kappa_{KL}(LM_{i}||LM_{j})=\mathcal{H}(LM_{i})-\mathcal{H}(LM_{i},LM_{j}). In addition, the function Fğ¹F is also computed via the formula F=âˆ‘i=1LÎº(Kâ€‹L,i)|L|ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¿subscriptğœ…ğ¾ğ¿ğ‘–ğ¿F=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{L}\kappa_{(KL,i)}}{|L|}, and the judge indicator F~~ğ¹\tilde{F} is also obtained by computing F~=âˆ‘Fin~ğ¹subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘›\tilde{F}=\frac{\sum{F_{i}}}{n}. According to different ratios Ï=|Fiâˆ’F~||F~|ğœŒsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–~ğ¹~ğ¹\rho=\frac{|F_{i}-\tilde{F}|}{|\tilde{F}|} and the threshold Î˜Î˜\Theta, the KLAD can treat models with weakly correlated rows as poisoned models and further eliminate them. Specifically, if the Î˜â‰¤ÏÎ˜ğœŒ\Theta\leq\rho, PDS removes the current detected local model; otherwise, it saves the current model and encrypts it to get ciphertext. Therefore, the KLAD algorithm is also effective in defense against data poisoning attacks and guarantees the security of local models.

VI-B Performance Analysis

To illustrate the effectiveness of the HHDP system, we utilize the standard Fashion-MINIST and GTSRB datasets for performance demonstration, concluding the influence of data poisoning attacks and two defense algorithms. The experiment environment with an Intel(R) Core(TM), i7-2600 CPU @3.40GHz, and 16.00GB of RAM, RTX3090 of GPU, is used to serve our central computational server. The parameters in HHDP are set up as the VCT number â„³=50â„³50\mathcal{M}=50. To show the performance of the HDDP system, we analyze the computational cost and give experimental simulations of the LMTV algorithm and KLAD algorithm based on the label-flipping attacks in data poisoning attacks.

VI-B4 Function of KLAD

The LMTV algorithm cannot realize the defense strategy if the PDS does not obtain the trust test dataset. Here, we should rely on the KLAD algorithm to detect poisoned local models. VII Conclusion

In this paper, we mainly achieve the defense against label-flipping attacks in FL. Specifically, we construct a novel framework to add a component of data poisoning defense to the traditional FL architecture. In particular, we adopt Paillier cryptography to ensure the security of transmission of local model parameters. More importantly, regarding whether there is a test dataset for the submitted local models, we design LMTV and KLAD defense algorithms to improve FL devicesâ€™ safety. Finally, we demonstrated the effectiveness of the LMTV and KLAD through some experiments evaluation on the real-world datasets. In the future, we will continue researching the data poisoning defense algorithms to optimize the modelâ€™s structure and improve defense performance without the trusted test dataset.
